text: file provides guidance Claude Code (claude.ai/code) working code repository.

title: CLAUDE.md
text: dfr.dist R package working dynamic failure rate (DFR) distributions survival analysis. package parameterizes distributions using flexible failure rate (hazard) functions can depend time set predictors/covariates.

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Always run devtools::document() modifying roxygen2 comments. NAMESPACE auto-generated - never edit manually.
code: devtools::document()      # Update NAMESPACE and .Rd files from roxygen2 devtools::build()         # Build package tarball devtools::check()         # Run R CMD check devtools::install()       # Install locally devtools::test()          # Run tests devtools::build_vignettes()    # Build vignettes pkgdown::build_site()          # Build package website

title: CLAUDE.md
text: central abstraction R/dfr_dist.R: rate: Function computing hazard rate h(t, par, …) par: Distribution parameters (can NULL unknown) eps: Epsilon numerical integration/sampling ob_col, delta_col: Column names survival data cum_haz_rate: Optional analytical H(t, par) AD gradient computation score_fn: Optional analytical score AD Hessian via Jacobian Inherits "univariate_dist" "dist" classes, implementing algebraic.dist interface.
code: dfr_dist(rate, par = NULL, eps = 0.01,          ob_col = "t", delta_col = "delta",          cum_haz_rate = NULL, score_fn = NULL)

title: CLAUDE.md
text: failure rate functions must satisfy: 1. Non-negativity: h(t, …) ≥ 0 t 2. Infinite cumulative hazard: lim(t→∞) H(t) = ∞, H(t) = ∫₀ᵗ h(u) du enforced code required mathematical correctness.

title: CLAUDE.md
text: distribution methods follow two-step pattern - understanding critical working package: Method called dfr_dist object, returning closure Closure accepts time t, parameters par, additional args ... enables flexible parameter handling late binding parameters (useful MLE).
code: # Create distribution d <- dfr_dist(rate = function(t, par, ...) par, par = 1)  # Get hazard function (returns closure) h <- hazard(d)  # Use the closure h(t = 5)              # Uses default par = 1 h(t = 5, par = 2)     # Overrides with par = 2

title: CLAUDE.md
text: dfr_dist class implements likelihood_model likelihood.model package:

title: CLAUDE.md
text: package optionally integrates femtograd exact gradient/Hessian computation: Score function fallback chain: 1. Analytical score_fn provided → exact 2. AD gradient via femtograd cum_haz_rate provided → exact 3. Numerical gradient via numDeriv::grad() → approximate Hessian fallback chain (hybrid approach): 1. AD Jacobian analytical score_fn via femtograd → exact 2. Numerical Hessian via numDeriv::hessian() → approximate hybrid approach (analytical gradient + AD Jacobian) often practical full AD : - Gradients easier derive analytically Hessians - Forward-mode AD Jacobian p-dimensional gradient costs O(p) passes - Works even full AD log-likelihood impractical Example analytical score:
code: exp_dist <- dfr_dist(     rate = function(t, par, ...) rep(par[1], length(t)),     cum_haz_rate = function(t, par, ...) par[1] * t,     score_fn = function(df, par, ...) {         c(sum(df$delta) / par[1] - sum(df$t))     } ) # Hessian computed via AD Jacobian of score_fn H <- hess_loglik(exp_dist) hess <- H(df, par = c(1))  # Uses femtograd if available

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Data frames passed likelihood methods use: - t column (ob_col): Observation times - delta column (delta_col): Event indicators - 1 = exact observation (failure) - 0 = right-censored (survived past time t) Log-likelihood contributions: - Exact: log L_i = log h(t_i) - H(t_i) - Censored: log L_i = -H(t_i)

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Cumulative hazard uses stats::integrate() defaults: - subdivisions = 1000L, abs_tol = 1e-3 (overridable) Sampling uses iterative rejection: 1. Start t = 0, sample Exp(rate(t, par)) 2. Accept runif(1) ≤ S(t, par), else increment t eps

title: CLAUDE.md
text: package designed work family related packages:
code: algebraic.dist          # Generic distribution interface (imported)     ↓ dfr.dist               # This package - DFR distributions     ↓ likelihood.model       # Likelihood model interface (dfr_dist satisfies this)     ↓ algebraic.mle          # MLE algebra for hypothesis testing, model selection     ↓ numerical.mle          # Optimization: gradient ascent, Newton-Raphson, etc.

title: CLAUDE.md
text: dfr_dist object satisfies likelihood_model interface, enabling:
code: # Fit DFR distribution to data using algebraic.mle library(algebraic.mle) mle_result <- mle(dfr_model, data, start_params)

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Two packages handle series systems (systems fail component fails) masked failure data (causing component uncertain): likelihood.model.series.md: Series system likelihood models masked component cause data. Currently implements exponential Weibull components. README explicitly mentions dfr_dist future integration general series systems arbitrary component hazard functions. mdrelax: Relaxed masking conditions series systems (Weibull/exponential). Integration potential: dfr_dist serve component distribution engine series systems, enabling time-dependent covariate-dependent component hazards beyond current exponential/Weibull implementations. architectural foundation exists likelihood.model.series.md’s utils.R (cum_haz(), qcomp(), rcomp() arbitrary hazard functions).

title: CLAUDE.md
text: algebraic.dist: Provides generics (hazard, cdf, pdf, surv, etc.) likelihood.model: Defines likelihood interface (loglik, score, hess_loglik) algebraic.mle: MLE algebra inference numerical.mle: Numerical optimization methods md.tools: Masked data utilities (Boolean matrix encoding/decoding)

title: CLAUDE.md
text: R/dfr_dist.R: Main S3 class methods (~440 lines) R/ad_utils.R: AD helpers femtograd integration R/generic_functions.R: Generic cum_haz() declaration R/utils.R: Helper get_params() parameter resolution R/reexports.R: Re-exports likelihood.model (loglik, score, etc.) tests/testthat/test-ad_integration.R: Tests AD integration tests/testthat/test-likelihood_model.R: Comprehensive tests likelihood interface vignettes/failure_rate.Rmd: Main tutorial

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Parameter handling: Always use params(x, par) handle NA/NULL correctly Integration warnings: Cumulative hazard uses numerical integration - check convergence Sampling efficiency: Rejection sampler can slow complex rate functions Closure pattern: Remember methods return functions, values directly AD compatibility: writing score_fn AD Hessian, use [[ indexing parameters (e.g., par[[1]] par[1]) work femtograd dual numbers

title: Automatic Differentiation for Maximum Likelihood Estimation
text: Maximum likelihood estimation (MLE) survival models requires computing derivatives log-likelihood function. score function (gradient) needed optimization, Hessian matrix (second derivatives) needed computing standard errors confidence intervals via observed Fisher information. dfr.dist package supports three approaches computing derivatives: Pure numerical differentiation - finite differences via numDeriv Full automatic differentiation - AD computes score Hessian Hybrid approach - analytical score + AD Jacobian Hessian vignette explores approaches using Weibull distribution case study, demonstrating hybrid approach offers best combination speed precision.

title: Automatic Differentiation for Maximum Likelihood Estimation
code:
library(dfr.dist)  # Check if femtograd is available for AD has_ad <- requireNamespace("femtograd", quietly = TRUE) if (has_ad) {   library(femtograd)   cat("femtograd available - AD examples will run
") } else {   cat("femtograd not installed - AD examples will be skipped
        Install with: devtools::install_github('queelius/femtograd')
") } #> femtograd available - AD examples will run

title: Automatic Differentiation for Maximum Likelihood Estimation
text: Weibull distribution widely used survival analysis. hazard function : h(t;k,σ)=kσ(tσ)k−1h(t; k, \sigma) = \frac{k}{\sigma}\left(\frac{t}{\sigma}\right)^{k-1} cumulative hazard : H(t;k,σ)=(tσ)kH(t; k, \sigma) = \left(\frac{t}{\sigma}\right)^k uncensored data, log-likelihood : ℓ(k,σ)=nlogk+(k−1)∑ilogti−nklogσ−∑(tiσ)k\ell(k, \sigma) = n\log k + (k-1)\sum_i \log t_i - nk\log\sigma - \sum_i \left(\frac{t_i}{\sigma}\right)^k

title: Automatic Differentiation for Maximum Likelihood Estimation
code:
set.seed(42) true_k <- 2 true_sigma <- 3 n <- 100  # Inverse CDF sampling for Weibull u <- runif(n) times <- true_sigma * (-log(u))^(1/true_k) df <- data.frame(t = times, delta = rep(1, n))  cat("Sample size:", n, "
") #> Sample size: 100 cat("True parameters: k =", true_k, ", sigma =", true_sigma, "
") #> True parameters: k = 2 , sigma = 3 cat("Sample mean:", round(mean(times), 3), "
") #> Sample mean: 2.634

title: Automatic Differentiation for Maximum Likelihood Estimation
text: simplest approach uses finite differences approximate derivatives. requires hazard rate function: Pros: Simple, analytical derivatives needed. Cons: Slow (many function evaluations), potential numerical precision issues.
code:
weibull_numerical <- dfr_dist(     rate = function(t, par, ...) {         k <- par[1]         sigma <- par[2]         (k / sigma) * (t / sigma)^(k - 1)     } )  # Get likelihood functions ll <- loglik(weibull_numerical) score_num <- score(weibull_numerical) hess_num <- hess_loglik(weibull_numerical)  # Evaluate at test point test_par <- c(1.8, 2.8)  cat("Log-likelihood:", ll(df, par = test_par), "

") #> Log-likelihood: -179.2143  cat("Score (numerical gradient):
") #> Score (numerical gradient): print(score_num(df, par = test_par)) #> [1] -10.494194   8.878177  cat("
Hessian (numerical):
") #>  #> Hessian (numerical): print(round(hess_num(df, par = test_par), 4)) #>          [,1]     [,2] #> [1,] -73.4602  30.3417 #> [2,]  30.3417 -50.2047

what: Approach 2: Hybrid - Analytical Score + AD Jacobian
title: Automatic Differentiation for Maximum Likelihood Estimation
text: score function Weibull can derived analytically: ∂ℓ∂k=nk+∑ilogti−nlogσ−∑(tiσ)klog(tiσ)\frac{\partial \ell}{\partial k} = \frac{n}{k} + \sum_i \log t_i - n\log\sigma - \sum_i \left(\frac{t_i}{\sigma}\right)^k \log\left(\frac{t_i}{\sigma}\right) ∂ℓ∂σ=kσ[∑(tiσ)k−n]\frac{\partial \ell}{\partial \sigma} = \frac{k}{\sigma}\left[\sum_i \left(\frac{t_i}{\sigma}\right)^k - n\right] provide analytical score, let AD compute Jacobian (gives us Hessian): Key point: score_fn uses par[[1]] indexing (double brackets) AD compatibility. allows femtograd’s dual numbers flow computation.
code:
weibull_hybrid <- dfr_dist(     rate = function(t, par, ...) {         k <- par[[1]]         sigma <- par[[2]]         (k / sigma) * (t / sigma)^(k - 1)     },     cum_haz_rate = function(t, par, ...) {         k <- par[[1]]         sigma <- par[[2]]         (t / sigma)^k     },     score_fn = function(df, par, ...) {         k <- par[[1]]         sigma <- par[[2]]         t <- df$t         n <- length(t)          # Vectorized computation         t_over_sigma <- t / sigma         t_over_sigma_k <- t_over_sigma^k          score_k <- n/k + sum(log(t)) - n*log(sigma) -                    sum(t_over_sigma_k * log(t_over_sigma))         score_sigma <- k/sigma * (sum(t_over_sigma_k) - n)          c(score_k, score_sigma)     } )  score_hybrid <- score(weibull_hybrid) hess_hybrid <- hess_loglik(weibull_hybrid)  cat("Score (analytical):
") #> Score (analytical): print(score_hybrid(df, par = test_par)) #> [1] -10.494704   8.878147  cat("
Hessian (AD Jacobian of analytical score):
") #>  #> Hessian (AD Jacobian of analytical score): print(round(hess_hybrid(df, par = test_par), 4)) #>          [,1]     [,2] #> [1,] -73.4609  30.3410 #> [2,]  30.3410 -50.2047

title: Automatic Differentiation for Maximum Likelihood Estimation
text: AD, can also compute score directly log-likelihood, get Hessian Jacobian score:
code:
weibull_full_ad <- dfr_dist(     rate = function(t, par, ...) {         k <- par[[1]]         sigma <- par[[2]]         (k / sigma) * (t / sigma)^(k - 1)     },     cum_haz_rate = function(t, par, ...) {         k <- par[[1]]         sigma <- par[[2]]         (t / sigma)^k     }     # No score_fn - AD will compute it from log-likelihood )  score_full_ad <- score(weibull_full_ad) hess_full_ad <- hess_loglik(weibull_full_ad)  cat("Score (AD gradient of log-likelihood):
") #> Score (AD gradient of log-likelihood): print(score_full_ad(df, par = test_par)) #> [1] -10.494704   8.878147  cat("
Hessian (AD Jacobian of AD score):
") #>  #> Hessian (AD Jacobian of AD score): print(round(hess_full_ad(df, par = test_par), 4)) #>          [,1]     [,2] #> [1,] -73.4602  30.3417 #> [2,]  30.3417 -50.2047

title: Automatic Differentiation for Maximum Likelihood Estimation
text: three approaches give similar results. Let’s compare: methods agree high precision (differences < 0.01).
code:
h_num <- hess_num(df, par = test_par) h_hybrid <- hess_hybrid(df, par = test_par) h_full <- hess_full_ad(df, par = test_par)  cat("Max absolute differences:
") #> Max absolute differences: cat("  Hybrid vs Numerical:", max(abs(h_hybrid - h_num)), "
") #>   Hybrid vs Numerical: 0.0006991277 cat("  Full AD vs Numerical:", max(abs(h_full - h_num)), "
") #>   Full AD vs Numerical: 0 cat("  Hybrid vs Full AD:", max(abs(h_hybrid - h_full)), "
") #>   Hybrid vs Full AD: 0.0006991277

title: Automatic Differentiation for Maximum Likelihood Estimation
text: real difference computational speed:
code:
# Warmup invisible(hess_num(df, par = test_par)) invisible(hess_hybrid(df, par = test_par)) invisible(hess_full_ad(df, par = test_par))  n_iter <- 20  # Numerical t0 <- Sys.time() for (i in 1:n_iter) invisible(hess_num(df, par = test_par)) time_num <- as.numeric(Sys.time() - t0) / n_iter * 1000  # Hybrid t0 <- Sys.time() for (i in 1:n_iter) invisible(hess_hybrid(df, par = test_par)) time_hybrid <- as.numeric(Sys.time() - t0) / n_iter * 1000  # Full AD t0 <- Sys.time() for (i in 1:n_iter) invisible(hess_full_ad(df, par = test_par)) time_full <- as.numeric(Sys.time() - t0) / n_iter * 1000  cat("Average time per Hessian computation:
") #> Average time per Hessian computation: cat(sprintf("  Numerical:      %7.2f ms
", time_num)) #>   Numerical:       108.58 ms cat(sprintf("  Hybrid (recommended): %7.2f ms
", time_hybrid)) #>   Hybrid (recommended):    1.55 ms cat(sprintf("  Full AD:        %7.2f ms
", time_full)) #>   Full AD:         107.65 ms cat(sprintf("
Speedup (Numerical / Hybrid): %.1fx
", time_num / time_hybrid)) #>  #> Speedup (Numerical / Hybrid): 70.2x

title: Automatic Differentiation for Maximum Likelihood Estimation
text: advantage hybrid approach grows sample size: hybrid approach stays nearly constant (~2ms) numerical scales linearly n.
code:
cat("Scaling with sample size:

") #> Scaling with sample size: cat(sprintf("%8s %10s %10s %8s
", "n", "Hybrid", "Numerical", "Speedup")) #>        n     Hybrid  Numerical  Speedup cat(sprintf("%8s %10s %10s %8s
", "---", "------", "---------", "-------")) #>      ---     ------  ---------  -------  for (sample_n in c(50, 100, 500, 1000)) {     set.seed(42)     times_bench <- true_sigma * (-log(runif(sample_n)))^(1/true_k)     df_bench <- data.frame(t = times_bench, delta = rep(1, sample_n))      # Time hybrid     t0 <- Sys.time()     for (i in 1:10) invisible(hess_hybrid(df_bench, par = test_par))     t_hybrid <- as.numeric(Sys.time() - t0) / 10 * 1000      # Time numerical     t0 <- Sys.time()     for (i in 1:5) invisible(hess_num(df_bench, par = test_par))     t_num <- as.numeric(Sys.time() - t0) / 5 * 1000      cat(sprintf("%8d %9.1f ms %9.1f ms %7.0fx
",                 sample_n, t_hybrid, t_num, t_num/t_hybrid)) } #>       50       1.3 ms      54.6 ms      42x #>      100       1.7 ms     107.9 ms      64x #>      500       1.4 ms     536.4 ms     384x #>     1000       1.8 ms    1107.3 ms     621x

what: Why is the Hybrid Approach Fastest?
title: Automatic Differentiation for Maximum Likelihood Estimation
text: Numerical differentiation requires many log-likelihood evaluations, involving numerical integration cumulative hazard. Full AD builds computation graphs every observation, significant overhead. Hybrid approach uses analytical score directly computes gradient without numerical integration. AD Jacobian requires 2 forward passes (one per parameter) efficient score function.

title: Automatic Differentiation for Maximum Likelihood Estimation
text: hybrid approach, score_fn must compatible femtograd’s dual numbers:

title: Automatic Differentiation for Maximum Likelihood Estimation
text: Use par[[1]] (double brackets) access parameters Use vectorized operations: t / sigma, t^k Use sum() reduce vectors scalars Use standard math functions: log(), exp(), ^

title: Automatic Differentiation for Maximum Likelihood Estimation
text: Don’t use par[1] (single bracket) - won’t extract dual numbers correctly Avoid control flow depends parameter values Don’t use functions don’t AD implementations

title: Automatic Differentiation for Maximum Likelihood Estimation
code: score_fn = function(df, par, ...) {     # Extract parameters with [[ ]]     theta1 <- par[[1]]     theta2 <- par[[2]]      # Get data (numeric, not dual)     t <- df$t     n <- length(t)      # Vectorized operations work with duals     z <- t / theta2      # Sum reduces to scalar dual     score1 <- n / theta1 - sum(z^theta1)     score2 <- -n * theta1 / theta2 + ...      # Return as vector     c(score1, score2) }

what: Computing Standard Errors and Confidence Intervals
title: Automatic Differentiation for Maximum Likelihood Estimation
text: Hessian, can compute standard errors via observed Fisher information:
code:
# Find MLE mle_result <- optim(c(1.5, 2.5),                     function(p) -ll(df, par = p),                     method = "L-BFGS-B",                     lower = c(0.1, 0.1)) mle_par <- mle_result$par  cat("MLE estimates:
") #> MLE estimates: cat("  k =", round(mle_par[1], 4), "(true:", true_k, ")
") #>   k = 1.7023 (true: 2 ) cat("  sigma =", round(mle_par[2], 4), "(true:", true_sigma, ")

") #>   sigma = 2.9636 (true: 3 )  # Hessian at MLE hess_mle <- hess_hybrid(df, par = mle_par)  # Observed Fisher information = -Hessian obs_info <- -hess_mle  # Standard errors = sqrt(diag(inverse Fisher info)) se <- sqrt(diag(solve(obs_info)))  cat("Standard errors:
") #> Standard errors: cat("  SE(k) =", round(se[1], 4), "
") #>   SE(k) = 0.1285 cat("  SE(sigma) =", round(se[2], 4), "

") #>   SE(sigma) = 0.1839  # 95% confidence intervals cat("95% Confidence Intervals:
") #> 95% Confidence Intervals: cat("  k: [", round(mle_par[1] - 1.96*se[1], 3), ",",     round(mle_par[1] + 1.96*se[1], 3), "]
") #>   k: [ 1.45 , 1.954 ] cat("  sigma: [", round(mle_par[2] - 1.96*se[2], 3), ",",     round(mle_par[2] + 1.96*se[2], 3), "]
") #>   sigma: [ 2.603 , 3.324 ]

title: Automatic Differentiation for Maximum Likelihood Estimation
text: Recommendation: production use, implement analytical score functions let AD compute Hessian via Jacobian. gives : 70-2000x speedup numerical (depending sample size) Exact derivatives (finite difference approximation) Automatic Hessian computation (manual second derivatives) initial effort derive score function pays substantially computational efficiency.

title: Dynamic Failure Rate Distributions
text: dfr.dist package provides flexible framework working survival distributions defined hazard (failure rate) functions. Instead choosing fixed catalog distributions, directly specify hazard function , giving complete flexibility model systems complex, time-varying failure patterns.

title: Dynamic Failure Rate Distributions
text: Traditional approaches use parametric families (Weibull, exponential, log-normal) impose strong assumptions failure rate behavior. hazard function h(t)h(t) provides intuitive parameterization reliability: Constant hazard: Exponential distribution (memoryless failures) Increasing hazard: Wear-phenomena Decreasing hazard: Burn-infant mortality Bathtub curve: Common electronics human mortality

title: Dynamic Failure Rate Distributions
text: lifetime random variable TT, instantaneous failure rate (hazard) : h(t)=limΔt→0Pr{T≤t+Δt|T>t}Δt=f(t)S(t) h(t) = \lim_{\Delta t \0} \frac{\Pr\{T \leq t + \Delta t | T > t\}}{\Delta t} = \frac{f(t)}{S(t)} cumulative hazard integrates instantaneous rate: H(t)=∫0th(u)du H(t) = \int_0^t h(u) \, du , quantities follow: Survival function: S(t)=exp(−H(t))S(t) = \exp(-H(t)) CDF: F(t)=1−S(t)F(t) = 1 - S(t) PDF: f(t)=h(t)⋅S(t)f(t) = h(t) \cdot S(t)

title: Dynamic Failure Rate Distributions
code: library(dfr.dist) library(algebraic.dist) #>  #> Attaching package: 'algebraic.dist' #> The following object is masked from 'package:grDevices': #>  #>     pdf

title: Dynamic Failure Rate Distributions
text: Use dfr_dist() create distribution hazard function: rate function must accept: t: time (scalar vector) par: parameter vector ...: additional arguments
code: # Exponential distribution: constant hazard h(t) = lambda exp_dist <- dfr_dist(   rate = function(t, par, ...) rep(par[1], length(t)),   par = c(lambda = 0.5) )  print(exp_dist) #> Dynamic failure rate (DFR) distribution with failure rate: #> <srcref: file "" chars 3:10 to 3:53> #> It has a survival function given by: #>     S(t|rate) = exp(-H(t,...)) #> where H(t,...) is the cumulative hazard function. is_dfr_dist(exp_dist) #> [1] TRUE

title: Dynamic Failure Rate Distributions
text: Weibull distribution hazard h(t)=kσ(tσ)k−1h(t) = \frac{k}{\sigma}\left(\frac{t}{\sigma}\right)^{k-1}:
code: weibull_dist <- dfr_dist(   rate = function(t, par, ...) {     k <- par[1]      # shape     sigma <- par[2]  # scale     (k / sigma) * (t / sigma)^(k - 1)   },   par = c(shape = 2, scale = 3) )

title: Dynamic Failure Rate Distributions
text: standard distribution functions available:

title: Dynamic Failure Rate Distributions
code: h <- hazard(exp_dist) H <- cum_haz(exp_dist)  # Evaluate at specific times h(1)      # Hazard at t=1 #> lambda  #>    0.5 h(c(1, 2, 3))  # Vectorized #> lambda lambda lambda  #>    0.5    0.5    0.5  H(2)      # Cumulative hazard at t=2 #> [1] 1

title: Dynamic Failure Rate Distributions
code: S <- surv(exp_dist) F <- cdf(exp_dist)  # Verify S(t) + F(t) = 1 t <- 2 c(survival = S(t), cdf = F(t), sum = S(t) + F(t)) #>  survival       cdf       sum  #> 0.3678794 0.6321206 1.0000000

title: Dynamic Failure Rate Distributions
code: # Use algebraic.dist::pdf to avoid masking by grDevices::pdf pdf_fn <- algebraic.dist::pdf(exp_dist)  # For exponential: f(t) = lambda * exp(-lambda * t) t <- 1 lambda <- 0.5 c(computed = pdf_fn(t), analytical = lambda * exp(-lambda * t)) #> computed.lambda      analytical  #>       0.3032653       0.3032653

title: Dynamic Failure Rate Distributions
code: Q <- inv_cdf(exp_dist)  # Median of exponential is log(2)/lambda median_computed <- Q(0.5) median_analytical <- log(2) / 0.5 c(computed = median_computed, analytical = median_analytical) #>   computed analytical  #>   1.386294   1.386294

title: Dynamic Failure Rate Distributions
code: samp <- sampler(exp_dist)  set.seed(42) samples <- samp(1000)  # Compare sample mean to theoretical mean (1/lambda = 2) c(sample_mean = mean(samples), theoretical = 1/0.5) #> sample_mean theoretical  #>     1.92733     2.00000

title: Dynamic Failure Rate Distributions
text: methods accept par argument override default parameters:
code: h <- hazard(exp_dist)  # Use default lambda = 0.5 h(1) #> lambda  #>    0.5  # Override with lambda = 2 h(1, par = c(2)) #> [1] 2

title: Dynamic Failure Rate Distributions
text: dfr_dist class implements likelihood_model interface, enabling maximum likelihood estimation survival data.

title: Dynamic Failure Rate Distributions
text: exact observations (failures known times): logLi=logh(ti)−H(ti) \log L_i = \log h(t_i) - H(t_i) right-censored observations (survived past time tt): logLi=−H(ti) \log L_i = -H(t_i)

title: Dynamic Failure Rate Distributions
code: # Simulate exact failure times from exponential(lambda=1) set.seed(123) true_lambda <- 1 n <- 50 times <- rexp(n, rate = true_lambda)  # Create data frame with standard survival format # delta = 1 means exact observation, delta = 0 means censored df_exact <- data.frame(t = times, delta = rep(1, n)) head(df_exact) #>            t delta #> 1 0.84345726     1 #> 2 0.57661027     1 #> 3 1.32905487     1 #> 4 0.03157736     1 #> 5 0.05621098     1 #> 6 0.31650122     1

title: Dynamic Failure Rate Distributions
text: log-likelihood highest near true parameter value.
code: dist <- dfr_dist(   rate = function(t, par, ...) rep(par[1], length(t)),   par = NULL  # No default - must be supplied )  ll <- loglik(dist)  # Evaluate at different parameter values ll(df_exact, par = c(0.5))  # lambda = 0.5 #> [1] -62.91663 ll(df_exact, par = c(1.0))  # lambda = 1.0 (true value) #> [1] -56.51854 ll(df_exact, par = c(2.0))  # lambda = 2.0 #> [1] -78.37973

title: Dynamic Failure Rate Distributions
text: score function gradient log-likelihood respect parameters. ’s computed numerically default:
code: s <- score(dist) s(df_exact, par = c(1.0))  # Should be close to 0 at MLE #> [1] -6.518543

title: Dynamic Failure Rate Distributions
code: H_ll <- hess_loglik(dist) hess <- H_ll(df_exact, par = c(1.0)) hess  # Should be negative (concave at maximum) #>      [,1] #> [1,]  -50

title: Dynamic Failure Rate Distributions
text: fit() function provides MLE estimation:
code: solver <- fit(dist)  # Find MLE starting from initial guess result <- solver(df_exact, par = c(0.5), method = "BFGS")  # Extract fitted parameters params(result) #> [1] 0.8846654  # Compare to analytical MLE: lambda_hat = n / sum(t) analytical_mle <- n / sum(times) c(fitted = params(result), analytical = analytical_mle, true = true_lambda) #>     fitted analytical       true  #>  0.8846654  0.8846654  1.0000000

title: Dynamic Failure Rate Distributions
text: Real survival data often includes censoring. ’s example mixed data:
code: # Some observations are censored (patient still alive at study end) df_mixed <- data.frame(   t = c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8),   delta = c(1, 1, 1, 0, 0, 1, 1, 0)  # 0 = censored )  ll <- loglik(dist)  # Fit with censored data solver <- fit(dist) result <- solver(df_mixed, par = c(0.5), method = "BFGS") #> Warning in log(h_exact): NaNs produced #> Warning in log(h_exact): NaNs produced #> Warning in log(h_exact): NaNs produced #> Warning in log(h_exact): NaNs produced #> Warning in log(h_exact): NaNs produced #> Warning in log(h_exact): NaNs produced #> Warning in log(h_exact): NaNs produced params(result) #> [1] 0.1388889

title: Dynamic Failure Rate Distributions
code: # Create Weibull DFR weibull <- dfr_dist(   rate = function(t, par, ...) {     k <- par[1]     sigma <- par[2]     (k / sigma) * (t / sigma)^(k - 1)   } )  # Simulate Weibull data (shape=2, scale=3) set.seed(456) true_shape <- 2 true_scale <- 3 n <- 100  # Use inverse CDF sampling u <- runif(n) weibull_times <- true_scale * (-log(u))^(1/true_shape)  df_weibull <- data.frame(t = weibull_times, delta = rep(1, n))  # Fit solver <- fit(weibull) result <- solver(df_weibull, par = c(1.5, 2.5), method = "BFGS")  c(fitted_shape = params(result)[1], true_shape = true_shape) #> fitted_shape   true_shape  #>      1.92518      2.00000 c(fitted_scale = params(result)[2], true_scale = true_scale) #> fitted_scale   true_scale  #>     2.788113     3.000000

title: Dynamic Failure Rate Distributions
text: real power dfr.dist modeling complex, non-standard hazard patterns.

title: Dynamic Failure Rate Distributions
text: classic bathtub curve three phases: 1. Infant mortality: High initial failure rate decreases 2. Useful life: Low, relatively constant failure rate 3. Wear-: Increasing failure rate components age
code: # h(t) = a * exp(-b*t) + c + d * t^k # Three components: infant mortality + baseline + wear-out bathtub <- dfr_dist(   rate = function(t, par, ...) {     a <- par[1]  # infant mortality magnitude     b <- par[2]  # infant mortality decay rate     c <- par[3]  # baseline hazard (useful life)     d <- par[4]  # wear-out coefficient     k <- par[5]  # wear-out exponent     a * exp(-b * t) + c + d * t^k   },   par = c(a = 1, b = 2, c = 0.02, d = 0.001, k = 2) )  # Plot the hazard function t_seq <- seq(0.01, 15, length.out = 200) h <- hazard(bathtub) plot(t_seq, sapply(t_seq, h), type = "l",      xlab = "Time", ylab = "Hazard rate",      main = "Bathtub hazard curve")

title: Dynamic Failure Rate Distributions
text: Hazards can depend covariates modify time effect:
code: # Proportional hazards with covariate x # h(t, x) = h0(t) * exp(beta * x) # where h0(t) = Weibull baseline  ph_model <- dfr_dist(   rate = function(t, par, x = 0, ...) {     k <- par[1]     sigma <- par[2]     beta <- par[3]     baseline <- (k / sigma) * (t / sigma)^(k - 1)     baseline * exp(beta * x)   },   par = c(shape = 2, scale = 3, beta = 0.5) )  h <- hazard(ph_model)  # Hazard for different covariate values h(2, x = 0)  # Baseline #>     shape  #> 0.4444444 h(2, x = 1)  # Higher risk group #>    shape  #> 0.732765

title: Dynamic Failure Rate Distributions
text: dfr_dist class inherits algebraic.dist classes, providing access additional functionality:
code: # Support is (0, Inf) for all DFR distributions support <- sup(exp_dist) print(support) #> (0, Inf)  # Parameters params(exp_dist) #> lambda  #>    0.5

title: Constructor for dfr_dist objects — dfr_dist
text: rate function computes hazard rate time t. par parameters distribution. Defaults NULL, means parameters unknown. eps epsilon update numerical integration. Defaults 0.01. ob_col column name observation times data frames. Defaults "t". delta_col column name event indicators data frames. Uses standard survival analysis convention: 1 = event observed (exact), 0 = right-censored. Defaults "delta". cum_haz_rate Optional analytical cumulative hazard function H(t, par). provided, enables exact AD-based gradient computation. return integral rate 0 t. score_fn Optional analytical score function score(df, par). provided, enables exact AD-based Hessian computation via Jacobian score. return gradient vector.

title: Sampling function for dfr_dist objects. — sampler.dfr_dist
text: Since S(t,par) = exp(-cum_hz(t,par)), can sample distribution letting t = 0 (positive number want condition T > t_min), sampling exponential distribution lambda = rate(t, par), rejecting sample runif(1) > S(t, par). accepted, add observation sample, otherwise reject , let t = t + eps eps small number, repeat. continue process n observations sample.
